thread.title: AFL 2015: Sydney Swans defeat Adelaide Crows at SCG in Round 18 | The
thread.title_full: AFL 2015: Sydney Swans defeat Adelaide Crows at SCG in Round 18 | The Advertiser

author: Neil Cordy
title: AFL 2015: Sydney Swans defeat Adelaide Crows at SCG in Round 18 | The
text:
ADAM Goodes wasn’t at the SCG, but he was there in spirit as the Swans found their best form of the season to beat the Adelaide Crows by 52 points at the SCG.
Wherever Goodes watched the game from, he would have been proud of his teammates who played with a spirit not seen since the Round 8 win over Hawthorn.
The crowd of 38,690 (the biggest at the SCG for the season) was full of home-made banners supporting Goodes and thousands more were wearing his famous number 37.
The Goodes-inspired win has put the Swans’ season back on track, as well as recent losses to the Hawks (89 points) and West Coast (52) in the rearview mirror.
Lewis Jetta produced a war dance of his own in support of Goodes last week and was again inspired against the Crows. His opening goal on the run from outside 50 was electric and he celebrated with another dance to lift the SCG crowd to their feet. He finished the day with 22 disposals seven marks.
Sydney Swans player Lewis Jetta performed a dance after booting the first goal of the game. Source: AAP
The Swans midfielders had a field day as they hit back to totally dominated possession (461-333).
Dan Hannebery led the way with another eyecatching display, finishing with a game-high 40 disposals and three goals.
The Swans had nine different goalscorers and six players with 30-plus disposals: Jarrad McVeigh (37), Luke Parker (30), Josh Kennedy (32), Dane Rampe (32) and Tom Mitchell (35).
Kieren Jack was also outstanding and had a hand in no less than nine scoring assists - the second-highest in AFL history behind Geelong champion Steve Johnson (11).
Kurt Tippett and Lance Franklin made an instant impact in their return from injury with three goals each.
Sydney Swans' Kurt Tippett booted three goals in the first game against his old side Adelaide. Source: AAP
Tippett played one of his best games for the Swans, going toe-to-toe with one of the best ruckmen in the league in Sam Jacobs then going forward to provide a target. He produced the form which could have a big impact for Sydney in the finals.
The Swans reclaimed their spot in the top four, which they temporarily lost to Richmond after their upset win over Hawthorn.
Crows indigenous players Eddie Betts and Charlie Cameron both had a message taped on their arms saying “I support Adam”. Betts contacted Goodes by phone before the match to let him know he wanted him to return to the game and play again.
Two of the highlights of a memorable night came before the first bounce.
The first was the Swans’ banner which simply read “RESPECT” in acknowledgment of Goodes’ struggles. The second was a standing ovation from virtually the whole crowd when a video of Goodes’ highlights was shown in the lead-up to the first bounce.
Josh Kennedy booted 32 disposals. Source: Getty Images
SYDNEY 17.15 (117)
ADELAIDE 9.11 (65)
GOALS
Sydney: D Hannebery 3, K Tippett 3, L Franklin 3, J Kennedy 2, L Parker 2, J Lloyd, J McVeigh, L Jetta, S Reid
Adelaide: T Lynch 3, J Jenkins 2, T Walker 2, E Betts, J Lyons
Umpires: Troy Pannell, Jacob Mollison, Dean Margetts.
Official Crowd: 38,690 at SCG
Originally published as Swans back in form, smash flat Crows
